answers: Urdu [prompt on Hindustani or Hindi–Urdu; do not accept or prompt on “Hindi”] (The poems are “Shikwa,” “Jawab-e-Shikwa,” and “Hum Dekhenge.”)
ghazals (“guzzles”)
Mirza Ghalib [or Mirza Asadullah Baig Khan] (According to Ghalib, being half-Muslim entails drinking alcohol but not eating pork.)
parts: Name this language. Iqbal Bano was a famous singer of Faiz Ahmad Faiz’s protest poem “We Will See” and other nazms in this national language of Pakistan.

Iqbal Bano was known for singing in this Persianate poetic form, as was Begum Akhtar, the “Queen” of this genre. Akhtar inspired Agha Shahid Ali, who wrote poems in this form containing couplets with rhyming radifs.

Jagjit Singh notably sang many of this poet’s Urdu ghazals. This rival of Zauq once quipped that he was “only half-Muslim,” and asked, “Who can beat a poet whose ghazals are sung by courtesans and fakirs in the streets?”

answers: chromatography [accept column chromatography or liquid chromatography or high-performance liquid chromatography; prompt on HPLC]
reversed-phase chromatography [or reverse-phase chromatography; prompt on RPC]
CBD AND THC [accept cannabidiol in place of “CBD”; accept delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol in place of “THC”]
parts: Name this class of techniques that separate mixtures by passing a mobile phase over a stationary phase. A column is used in its “high-performance liquid” type.

This type of liquid chromatography separates mixtures by hydrophobicity. Unlike older approaches, it uses an aqueous mobile phase and a nonpolar stationary phase, such as silica coated with 18-carbon chains.

RPC separates these two compounds, since one has a hydroxyl group where the other has an ether. Strong acid cyclizes the non-intoxicating first one of these two compounds to produce the potent delta-9 form of the other.

answers: Cleitus the Black [or Clitus the Black]
Companion Cavalry [or hetairoi; or Companions; do not accept or prompt on “Companion Infantry”]
Philip II of Macedon [or Philip of Macedon; prompt on Philip]
parts: Name this Macedonian, whom Alexander later impulsively killed after they quarreled at a symposium at Maracanda. He is called “the Black” to distinguish him from a homonymous Macedonian known as “the White.”

After Philotas was executed, Cleitus became the joint leader of this elite force, Alexander’s shock cavalry, with Hephaestion. This force was divided into ilai, one of which served as a royal squadron led by Alexander.

Arrian suggests that the drunk Cleitus belittled the achievements of Alexander and praised those of this man, Alexander’s father. This man was killed by his bodyguard Pausanias shortly before his planned invasion of Persia.

answers: French Suites OR English Suites OR Partitas [accept answers like Partitas for keyboard or Partitas for harpsichord in place of “Partitas”]
Italian Concerto [or Concerto nach Italienischen Gusto; or Concerto in the Italian Taste; or BWV 971]
theme and variations [accept Goldberg Variations]
parts: Bach’s suites for solo keyboard are commonly grouped into several named sets. Name any two of those sets.

This three-movement piece for two-manual harpsichord [emphasize] does not have orchestral accompaniment, despite its name. This F major piece was paired with a “French Overture” in the second book of Clavier-Übung.
Another solo harpsichord work by Bach is a long piece in this form that begins with an “Aria” movement. That 31-movement work in this musical form is named for “Goldberg.”

answers: corruption [prompt on bribery]
soft money
campaign finance vouchers
parts: Name this practice. Justice Roberts only recognized the “quid-pro-quo” variety of it in his opinion in McCutcheon v. FEC, but more generally, this term refers to abuse of power or public office for private gain.

Advocates of campaign finance reform decry this practice of allowing unlimited donations to political committees. The McCain–Feingold Act banned these donations, but the McCutcheon decision reinstated them.

Seattle adopted a method of campaign finance reform that uses these items, which can be redeemed for public funds. The Seattle Ethics and Elections committee will mail voters four of these items for every city election cycle.

answers: An Lushan Rebellion [or An-Shi Rebellion; or An-Shi Disturbances; or Tianbao Rebellion]
baojia system [or pao-chia system]
Qing dynasty
parts: Name this conflict against the Emperor Xuanzong (“shwen-dzong”). It was blamed on the family of Yang Guifei (“yong gway-fay”), who was put to death during it.

Following the Tang dynasty, the census was conducted using this system, which divided areas into units of 10 and 100 households. It was officially implemented by Wang Anshi, who sought to strengthen local militias with it.
The baojia system was revitalized by this dynasty’s Kangxi emperor, who instead used it to suppress the local population. This dynasty was established in 1644 by Manchus invading the Ming dynasty.

answers: My Year of Rest and Relaxation
9/11 [or September 11, 2001 attacks; or World Trade Center attacks; or equivalents]
Don DeLillo (The novel is White Noise.)
parts: Name this novel by Ottessa Moshfegh whose protagonist strives to sleep as much as possible with the assistance of the quack Dr. Tuttle and the artist Ping Xi after she is fired from her gallery job.
In My Year of Rest and Relaxation, the narrator’s former roommate at Columbia dies in this event, which is depicted in Falling Man and Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close.
This author wrote about the title performance artist re-enacting a scene from 9/11 in Falling Man. In another novel by this author, Babette takes the drug Dylar to avoid the fear of death.

answers: footnotes [prompt on notes]
Russia (Those thinkers are Nikolai Berdyaev and Leo Tolstoy.)
“What Is It Like to Be a Bat?”
parts: Alfred North Whitehead claimed that Western philosophy “consists of a series of” what items to Plato? Unlike their “end” counterparts, these addendums common in academic papers are printed at the bottom of the page.

A thinker from this country used the infamous footnote “This was once revealed to me in a dream.” Another thinker from this country argued that the “religious perception” of an age determines aesthetic value in What is Art?

The author imagines a “tiny image” of the Mona Lisa in his brain in a footnote of this essay, whose footnote 11 is an influential reply to Kripke. This Thomas Nagel essay discusses consciousness and the mind–body problem.

answers: headaches [accept post-dural-puncture headaches; or PDPH; prompt on head pain; do not accept or prompt on “migraines”]
meningitis [accept fungal meningitis or bacterial meningitis]
stiff neck [or nuchal rigidity; or word forms like neck stiffness; prompt on stiffness or rigidity]
parts: Name these conditions that can come in “cluster” varieties. “Searing” conditions of this kind can follow spinal anaesthesia or lumbar punctures because the puncture causes a CSF leak, lowering intracranial pressure.

Lumbar punctures can help diagnose this condition, an inflammation of the brain’s protective layer consisting of the dura, pia, and arachnoid mater. Cryptococcus and Neisseria are common causes of this condition.
Post-dural-puncture headaches may present with this symptom, also characteristic of meningitis. A positive Brudzinski’s sign results from this symptom in meningitis patients.

answers: harp
Alice Coltrane [prompt on Coltrane; accept Alice Hagood; or Alice McLeod; or Turiyasangitananda]
Japan [or Nippon]
parts: Name this instrument played by another woman as bandleader on albums such as Journey in Satchidananda and World Galaxy.
World Galaxy is an album by this musician, who played on songs such as “Naima” after replacing McCoy Tyner as pianist in her husband’s quintet.

Alice and John Coltrane traveled to this country on their last tour before John’s death. The Rubaiyat of Dorothy Ashby features the koto, an instrument from this country home to jazz pianists Ryo Fukui and Hiromi.

answers: “The God Abandons Antony”
Constantine Peter Cavafy [or Konstantinos Petrou Kavafis] (The poem is “Waiting for the Barbarians.”)
Ulysses [or Odysseus]
parts: Name this poem based on a story from Plutarch’s Lives that ends “say goodbye to her, to the Alexandria you are losing.”
This author of “The God Abandons Antony” wrote a poem that asks “What are we waiting for, assembled in the forum?” and “Why are the senators sitting there without legislating?”
Cavafy writes “hope your road is a long one” in “Ithaka,” a poem referencing this man. A poem by Tennyson named for this hero ends “To strive, to seek, to find, and not to yield.”

answers: Austria [accept First Austrian Republic; accept Federal State of Austria]
Anschluss
Franz Joseph I [prompt on Franz Joseph]
parts: Name this country whose politics following World War I were split between its Social Democratic Party and the Christian Social Party. Following a civil war in this country, the Fatherland Front established one-party rule.

Despite being fascists, the Fatherland Front sought to prevent this event, the absorption of Austria into the Third Reich. Following this 1938 event, Kurt Schuschnigg (“SHOOSH-nig”) resigned as Austrian chancellor.

This person refused to confirm Karl Lueger, founder of the Christian Social Party, as mayor of Vienna until Leo XIII intervened. This man’s only son committed suicide with his lover in the Mayerling Incident.

answers: the truth [accept true love or real love; accept “Ana’l-Haqq” (the original shath in Arabic); accept ishq-e-haqeeqi]
Ghazali [accept (Majd al-Dīn Abū al-Fotuh) Ahmad Ghazālī or (Abū Hāmid Muhammad ibn Muhammad at-Tūsiyy) al-Ghazālī]
Ali ibn abi Talib
parts: The most famous shath ever uttered was one in which Mansur al-Hallaj claimed to be this concept, leading to his execution. This concept also names a form of love contrasted with ishq-e-majāzi.

al-Hallaj influenced one jurist of this surname whose own teachings on love mirror al-Hallaj’s. That man’s more famous brother also admired al-Hallaj despite frowning both on his shath and Ibn Sina’s Aristotelian falsafa.

The shathiyat can be considered a part of the “hidden knowledge” only accessible to select people, such as this nephew of Muhammad, whom he called the “gate to the city of knowledge.” This man is also the first Shia imam.

answers: heat equation
second law of thermodynamics [prompt on partial answer]
transport [accept transport coefficients or Boltzmann transport equation]
parts: Name this parabolic partial differential equation, whose diffusivity coefficient relates the time derivative and Laplacian of a variable usually denoted u. It has the same form as Fick’s second law for diffusion.
The flow of heat from warmer to colder bodies is consistent with the Clausius statement of this law, which more generally states that the entropy of the universe tends to increase.

Onsager’s reciprocal relations link heat fluxes to density gradients via a matrix of coefficients named for this process. This process also names an equation derived by assuming Stosszahlansatz (“SHTOSS-zahl-ON-zotts”), or molecular chaos.

answers: surveying [or word forms like surveyors; prompt on answers like cartography or map-making by asking “what discipline did they use to make maps?”]
Benjamin Banneker
David Rittenhouse
parts: Name this discipline used to measure distances on land, which was used to define the Mason–Dixon line.

This African-American surveyor worked with Andrew Ellicot to establish the borders of Washington, D.C. This astronomer published several almanacs and wrote a letter criticizing Thomas Jefferson for supporting slavery.
This Philadelphia mathematician proofread Banneker’s almanacs. Along with Ellicot, this first director of the US Mint finished surveying the Mason–Dixon line.

Zadie Smith

parts: Name this author who traced the interconnected lives of twelve characters in that novel, which includes the farmer Hattie, her nonbinary grandchild Morgan, and Amma, who writes the play The Last Amazon of Dahomey.
Evaristo was featured in the 2019 anthology New Daughters of Africa, which also included a “Speech to Langston” delivered by this author of On Beauty and White Teeth.

In Girl, Woman, Other, Yazz befriends the “Unfuckwithables,” including the lower-class Courtney, at one of these places, the main setting of On Beauty. In White Teeth, Marcus Chalfen creates the FutureMouse at one of them.

answers: dataflow programming [prompt on flow-based programming]
graphs [accept directed graphs; accept flow networks or transportation networks; prompt on trees]
source AND sink
parts: Name this programming paradigm contrasted with control flow, which focuses on the movement of inputs and outputs through a pipeline of black-box operators. It is often used in hardware description languages like Verilog.
Dataflow languages model programs as the “directed” form of these mathematical entities, which are composed of nodes and edges. Each edge has a capacity in a “flow” one of these entities.

Two answers required. In a flow network, one of these two named nodes only has outgoing flow, and the other only has incoming flow. The Ford–Fulkerson algorithm calculates max flow by finding paths from one of these nodes to the other.

answers: Supper at Emmaus
Caravaggio [or Michelangelo Merisi da Caravaggio; do not accept or prompt on “Michaelangelo”]
Johannes Vermeer (The forgeries were painted by Hans van Meegeren.)
parts: Give this scene depicting the shock of two disciples, one wearing a shell pinned to his shirt, as Jesus raises his arm to bless bread. A later version of this scene adds an old woman with a tray of ribs and a pitch-black background.

This artist painted two depictions of the Supper at Emmaus, the later version after he fled Rome for the murder of Ranuccio Tommasoni. Jesus beckons a shocked tax collector in this tenebrist artist’s Calling of St. Matthew.

The composition of Caravaggio’s Supper at Emmaus inspired a notable 20th-century forgery imitating this artist. Christ with the Woman Taken by Adultery, another forgery imitating this artist, ended up in Hermann Goering’s collection.

Sudan [or North Sudan; or the Republic of the Sudan; or Jumhūriyyat as-Sūdān; do not accept or prompt on “South Sudan”] (Ethiopia summoned the US Ambassador to explain Trump’s comments the following day.)
African Union [or AU]
parts: Name this country that is financing its 4.8-billion-dollar “Grand Renaissance Dam” with bonds and donations to avoid relying on foreign powers.
Donald Trump nonsensically declared that Egypt would blow up the dam on an October 2020 phone call with this country’s prime minister Abdalla Hamdok, announcing this country’s recognition of Israel.
Sudan withdrew from a new round of dam negotiations in January 2021, demanding that this continent-wide intergovernmental organization headquartered in Addis Ababa be involved as mediator.

answers: crying [or weeping; or equivalents]
Mount Sipylus [accept Mount Spil or Spil Daği]
Diomedes (The chariot race happens in Book XXIII, during the funeral games of Patroclus; the enemy referenced is Aphrodite.)
parts: Give this action that Balius and Xanthus perform while standing on the battlefield after the death of Patroclus. Niobe performs this action incessantly after Artemis and Apollo kill all of her children, even after she turns to stone.

Niobe was turned into stone as she cried atop this mountain, thus becoming the Weeping Rock facing Manisa. Pausanias claimed that Broteas, the son of Tantalus, carved a relief of Cybele (“SIB-uh-lee”) into this mountain.

This hero is the only one to cry in a context outside of war in the Iliad, when Apollo makes him drop his whip in a chariot race. This hero wounds one enemy on the wrist during his aristeia, and later trades armor with Glaucus.
